Tavatron shut her optics tightly as Necromancer became airborn. She had 
never been very fond of flying, but could tolerate it to a certain extent. 
She kept her gaze focused on the dragon's massive head, and did her best NOT 
to look down. The wind whipped past her, pushing back her fur and loosening 
various flora that had been embedded in her fur. If anything this flight 
would make brushing her fur easier.

With a heavy sigh Tavatron crossed her arms and rested them atop 
Necromancer's back. Her head was slightly raised, but eventually that too 
was resting atop the massive dragon. Despite her earlier nap she was still 
tired. Her shoulder throbbed occasionally, but otherwise was fine. Thinking 
of her own injuries made her wonder how Dinobot was doing. She was still 
upset at him, but not nearly as angry as she was before. His words still 
echoed in her mind, but instead of immediatly returning his verbal attack 
with one of her own she had decided to think it over first. She still 
couldn't figure out WHY he was so upset. Sure, she was missing her shoulder 
plate, big deal. She had been in worse condition and lived:

"Dinobot, can I ask you something?"

Her tone was normal, and rather hard to understand considering she still had 
her optics closed and had proceeded to cover them with her arms. It just 
made the flight easier. Once she was on the ground she would be alright. 
Until then she wasn't budging an inch:

"Why do you care whether or not I'm scrapped? What difference does it make? 
I'm no one important, just another soldier in another pointless war."

Whether he chose to ignore her or continue yelling at her was up to him. 
Right now her only real concern was getting back on the ground. For some 
reason the thought of Dinobot not making it back to base in time never 
crossed her mind. She just assumed, as always, that he would be alright. The 
thought of him NOT being alright was something she wasn't even willing to 
consider. Despite their current argument Tavatron still considered him a 
friend. Unfortunetly, a friendship could only take a certain amount of 
strain before it snapped.
